greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k) by rows: number of ways k dominoes can be placed on an n X n chessboard, k>=0.
comment: Also, coefficients of the matching-generating polynomial of the n X n grid graph.
In the n-th row there are floor(n^2/2)+1 values.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..14, flattened
Ralf Stephan, Two dominoes on the 3x3 chessboard, illustration of T(3,2)=44.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Grid Graph
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Matching-Generating Polynomial
Index entries for sequences related to dominoes
Index entries for sequences related to matchings
maple: b:= proc(n, l) option remember; local k;
elif min(l[])>0 then b(n-1, map(h->h-1, l))
else for k while l[k]>0 do od; expand(`if`(n>1,
x*b(n, subsop(k=1, k+1=1, l)), 0) +b(n, subsop(k=1, l)))
T:= n-> (p-> seq(coeff(p, x, i), i=0..degree(p)))(b(n, [0$n])):
mathematica: b[n_, l_List] := b[n, l] =  Module[{k}, Which[n == 0, 1, Min[l]>0, b[n-1, l-1], True, For[k=1, l[[k]]>0, k++]; Expand[If[n>1, x*b[n, ReplacePart[l, k -> 2]], 0] + If[k<Length[l] && l[[k+1]] == 0, x*b[n, ReplacePart[l, {k -> 1, k + 1 -> 1}]], 0] + b[n, ReplacePart[l, k -> 1]]]]]; T[n_] := Function[{p}, Table[Coefficient[p, x, i], {i, 0, Exponent[p, x]}]][b[n, Array[0&, n]]]; Table[T[n], {n, 0, 8}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 16 2015, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Ralf Stephan_, May 24 2014
